content.title: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)
content.summary: Bleeding into the subarachnoid space, most commonly from ruptured cerebral aneurysm
key_points: 'Worst headache of my life' - thunderclap onset
CT head sensitivity 95-98% in first 6 hours; LP if CT negative
Emergent neurosurgical consultation for aneurysm securing
Nimodipine prevents delayed cerebral ischemia from vasospasm
Hunt-Hess and Fisher grades predict outcomes

statement.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, typically from ruptured intracranial aneurysm. Classic presentation is sudden severe 'thunderclap' headache. Diagnosis requires CT (highly sensitive early) and lumbar puncture if CT is negative. Treatment involves aneurysm securing and prevention of vasospasm.
statement.formal: SAH = Thunderclap headache + CT showing subarachnoid blood (or xanthochromic LP) → CTA to find aneurysm → Secure aneurysm + Nimodipine + ICU monitoring

explanation.intuition: SAH is a blood vessel (usually an aneurysm) popping on the surface of the brain, spilling blood into the CSF space. The sudden headache comes from blood irritating the meninges. The blood sets off a cascade of dangerous complications: rebleeding, vasospasm, hydrocephalus.
explanation.key_insight: SAH is a neurosurgical emergency with high mortality (30-50%). The key treatable complication is vasospasm (peaks day 4-14), which causes delayed cerebral ischemia. Nimodipine, a calcium channel blocker, improves outcomes by preventing vasospasm.

definitions_glossary.subarachnoid_hemorrhage: Bleeding into space between arachnoid and pia mater (subarachnoid space)
definitions_glossary.thunderclap_headache: Severe headache reaching maximum intensity within seconds; SAH until proven otherwise
definitions_glossary.saccular_aneurysm: Berry aneurysm - outpouching at arterial bifurcation; most common SAH cause
definitions_glossary.xanthochromia: Yellow discoloration of CSF from hemoglobin breakdown; indicates prior bleeding
definitions_glossary.vasospasm: Arterial narrowing days 4-14 after SAH; causes delayed cerebral ischemia
definitions_glossary.delayed_cerebral_ischemia: DCI - neurologic deterioration from vasospasm; major SAH complication
definitions_glossary.nimodipine: Calcium channel blocker reducing DCI; given for 21 days
definitions_glossary.Hunt_Hess_grade: Clinical grading (I-V) based on symptoms; predicts outcome
definitions_glossary.Fisher_grade: CT grading based on blood distribution; predicts vasospasm risk
definitions_glossary.rebleeding: Second hemorrhage from same aneurysm; highest risk first 24 hours
definitions_glossary.hydrocephalus: CSF obstruction from blood; may need EVD
definitions_glossary.triple_H_therapy: Historical treatment (hypertension, hemodilution, hypervolemia) for vasospasm; now mainly induced HTN

pathophysiology.aneurysm_formation: Hemodynamic stress at arterial bifurcations → wall weakening → saccular outpouching

clinical: Focal deficits (from aneurysm mass effect or ischemia)

imaging.CT_head: Hyperdense blood in subarachnoid space, cisterns, sulci; 95-98% sensitive <6h, drops to 58% at day 5
imaging.LP_if_CT_negative: RBCs in CSF (may clear tube 1→4 if traumatic tap); xanthochromia (present after 6-12h)
imaging.digital_subtraction_angiography: Gold standard if CTA negative but high suspicion

initial_management: ABCs and secure airway if obtunded

aneurysm_treatment.endovascular_coiling: Preferred for most aneurysms; lower procedural morbidity (ISAT trial)
aneurysm_treatment.surgical_clipping: For certain anatomies, wide-necked aneurysms, or with significant hematoma

vasospasm_prevention_treatment.nimodipine: Oral 60mg q4h × 21 days; reduces DCI and improves outcomes
vasospasm_prevention_treatment.monitoring: Transcranial Doppler (TCD) to detect vasospasm; velocities >120-200 cm/s
vasospasm_prevention_treatment.treatment_of_DCI: Induced hypertension (allow SBP up to 200); intra-arterial vasodilators, angioplasty

treatment_options.hydrocephalus: EVD for acute hydrocephalus; may need VP shunt if chronic
supportive: Avoid hyponatremia (common from SIADH/cerebral salt wasting)

definition.@value: Bleeding into the subarachnoid space, most commonly from ruptured cerebral aneurysm, presenting with sudden severe headache

learning_objectives: Recognize thunderclap headache as SAH until proven otherwise
Apply Ottawa SAH Rule to determine CT/LP need
Interpret CT and LP findings for SAH diagnosis
Know indications for coiling vs clipping
clinical_pearls: CT sensitivity drops significantly after 6 hours - must do LP if negative but suspicious
Xanthochromia takes 6-12 hours to develop - if LP done too early, may be just RBCs
Vasospasm peaks days 4-14 - this is the highest risk period post-SAH
Nimodipine improves outcomes - don't forget it
Hyponatremia is common - SIADH or cerebral salt wasting; manage carefully

sources.source: Connolly ES, et al. AHA/ASA SAH Guideline 2012. Stroke 2012
